So what is to be done? I joined colleagues in making some suggestions to President Biden here, from better reporting of hate crimes, to grants to relevant non-profits, to appointing a State Dept. envoy to fight anti-Semitism (a position I used to supervise). 7/ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2lLaK0WQAMM9R3.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2lMX3GWUAMmZ-0.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2lM0LrWYAUHk8Q.jpg

One caveat: anti-Semitism from the far right remains virulent, with Nazis disrupting pro-Israel rallies & a huge spike in anti-Semitic messaging on the right wing message board 4Chan. But this is all the more reason for all of us to watch our language. 6/ https://www.bostonherald.com/2021/05/25/disgusting-and-despicable-neo-nazi-group-gathers-in-front-of-new-england-holocaust-memorial-in-boston/

But words like "genocide" & "apartheid" go beyond criticism of Israeli gov't policies; whatever their technical meaning, they invite rejection of the state and idea of Israel itself.

With the fuel of latent anti-Semitism all around us, such words can be like sparks to a fire. 5/

I have constituents, some with deep family ties to the West Bank & Gaza, who condemn the policies of the current Israeli government, and who urge the U.S. (fairly in my view) to do more for the human rights of Palestinians. Agree or not, these are legitimate arguments to make. 4/

The attacks have spiked alongside the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Some who are angry at Israel are transferring  hostility to Jews in general; others feel recent events give them permission to act on anti-Semitic views that were always there.

None of this is acceptable. 3/

In recent years, most anti-Semitic attacks in America have come from the far right. But the latest surge seems to be coming more from the fringes of the left. Democrats & progressives must show leadership here, just as we've demanded of the other side. 2/

May 28th must be remembered alongside January 6th as the day that 35 U.S. Senators, representing a minority of Americans, put their personal political future ahead of the future of our democracy.

The bipartisan majority voted in favor of a January 6th commission in fear of what further damage could be inflicted on our democracy. The minority used the un-democratic filibuster to block it in fear of losing elections.
I, along with the majority of members of the House and Senate, on a bipartisan basis and representing the vast majority of Americans, voted AGAINST doing nothing in response to the insurrection.

Voting to block the bipartisan 1/6 commission was the minority‚Äôs way of declaring that doing nothing is their response to keeping Capitol Police, congressional staff, and members themselves safe from future attacks.
Voting to block the bipartisan 1/6 commission was the minority‚Äôs way of declaring that doing nothing is their response to the greatest number of first responder injuries since September 11th.

Voting to block the bipartisan 1/6 commission was the minority‚Äôs way of declaring that doing nothing is their response to the death of a Capitol Police officer who came to work every day to protect them.

Voting to block the bipartisan 1/6 commission was the minority‚Äôs way of declaring that doing nothing is their response to an attack focused on taking hostage not just the physical documents declaring the winner of the election, but the Vice President of the United States.
Voting to block the bipartisan 1/6 commission yesterday was the minority‚Äôs way of declaring that doing nothing is their response to an attack on our democracy.

As I read the names of the 35 Senators who blocked the bipartisan 1/6 Commission, I thought of a quote of unknown origin, often misattributed to the great Irish statesman Sir Edmund Burke: ‚ÄúThe only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good people to do nothing.‚Äù http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2kkk7vX0AYrdnW.jpg
